home arena of the New Orleans Pelicans

The **New Orleans Pelicans** are an American professional
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") team based in [New Orleans,
Louisiana](/wiki/New_Orleans,_Louisiana "New Orleans, Louisiana"). The
Pelicans compete in the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA) as a member club of the league's [Western
Conference](/wiki/Western_Conference_\(NBA\) "Western Conference \(NBA\)")
[Southwest Division](/wiki/Southwest_Division_\(NBA\) "Southwest Division
\(NBA\)"). The team plays their home games in the [Smoothie King
Center](/wiki/Smoothie_King_Center "Smoothie King Center") (formerly known as
the New Orleans Arena).

The Pelicans were established as the **New Orleans Hornets** in the [2002–03
season](/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_NBA_season "2002–03 NBA season") when then-owner
of the [Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte Hornets"),
[George Shinn](/wiki/George_Shinn "George Shinn"),
[relocated](/wiki/Relocation_of_professional_sports_teams "Relocation of
professional sports teams") the franchise to New Orleans. Due to the damage
caused by [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina") in
2005, the franchise [temporarily
relocated](/wiki/Effect_of_Hurricane_Katrina_on_the_New_Orleans_Hornets
"Effect of Hurricane Katrina on the New Orleans Hornets") to [Oklahoma
City](/wiki/Oklahoma_City "Oklahoma City"), where they spent two seasons
officially known as the **New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets**. The team
returned to New Orleans full-time for the [2007–08
season](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_NBA_season "2007–08 NBA season"). On January 24,
2013, the franchise announced it would rename itself the Pelicans,[7]
effective after the conclusion of the [2012–13
season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NBA_season "2012–13 NBA season"). The Charlotte
Hornets name, history and records from 1988 to 2002 were returned to its
original city to be used by the then–Charlotte Bobcats franchise, which
subsequently became the [Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte
Hornets"), starting May 20, 2014.[1]

In 14 seasons of play since the original franchise relocated from North
Carolina, the Louisiana franchise has achieved an overall regular season
record of 528–604, and has qualified for the [playoffs](/wiki/NBA_playoffs
"NBA playoffs") six times. Their achievements include one playoff series
victory and one division title.

## Franchise
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Franchise history")]

Main article: [History of the New Orleans
Pelicans](/wiki/History_of_the_New_Orleans_Pelicans "History of the New
Orleans Pelicans")

### Relocation to New
Orleans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Relocation to New Orleans")]

While the Charlotte Hornets put a competitive team on the court throughout the
1990s, the team's attendance began falling dramatically. Many attributed this
lapse in popularity to the team's owner, [George Shinn](/wiki/George_Shinn
"George Shinn"), who was slowly becoming despised by the people of the
city.[8] In 1997, a Charlotte woman claimed that Shinn had raped her, and the
resulting trial severely tarnished his reputation in the city. The consensus
was that while Charlotte was as basketball-crazy as ever, fans took out their
anger at Shinn on the team. Shinn had also become discontented with the
[Charlotte Coliseum](/wiki/Charlotte_Coliseum "Charlotte Coliseum"), which,
although considered state-of-the-art when it opened in 1988, had by then been
considered obsolete due to a limited number of luxury boxes. On March 26,
2001, both the Hornets and the [Vancouver Grizzlies](/wiki/Vancouver_Grizzlies
"Vancouver Grizzlies") applied for relocation to [Memphis,
Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"),[9] which was
ultimately [won by the
Grizzlies](/wiki/Vancouver_Grizzlies_relocation_to_Memphis "Vancouver
Grizzlies relocation to Memphis"). Shinn issued an ultimatum: unless the city
built a new arena at no cost to him, the Hornets would leave town. The city
initially refused, leading Shinn to consider moving the team to either
[Norfolk](/wiki/Norfolk,_Virginia "Norfolk, Virginia"),
[Louisville](/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky "Louisville, Kentucky"), or [St.
Louis](/wiki/St._Louis "St. Louis"). Of the cities in the running, only St.
Louis had an NBA-ready arena (Savvis Center, now known as [Scottrade
Center](/wiki/Scottrade_Center "Scottrade Center")) already in place and was a
larger media market than Charlotte at the time; also, it was the only one of
the four to have previously hosted an NBA franchise — the [St. Louis
Hawks](/wiki/St._Louis_Hawks "St. Louis Hawks"), who moved to
[Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta") in 1968.

Finally, a new arena in [Uptown](/wiki/Charlotte_center_city "Charlotte center
city"), which would eventually become the Charlotte Bobcats Arena (now known
as [Spectrum Center](/wiki/Spectrum_Center_\(arena\) "Spectrum Center
\(arena\)")), was included in a non-binding referendum for a larger arts-
related package, and Shinn withdrew his application to move the team. Polls
showed the referendum on its way to passage. However, just days before the
referendum, Mayor [Pat McCrory](/wiki/Pat_McCrory "Pat McCrory") vetoed a
[living wage](/wiki/Living_wage "Living wage") ordinance. The veto prompted
many of the city's black ministers to oppose the referendum; they felt it was
immoral for the city to build a new arena when city employees weren't paid
enough to make a living.[10] After the referendum failed, city leaders devised
a plan to build a new arena in a way that did not require voter support, but
made it known that they would not even consider building it unless Shinn sold
the team. While even the NBA acknowledged that Shinn had alienated fans,
league officials felt such a demand would anger other owners.[11] The city
council refused to remove the statement, leading the Hornets to request a move
to New Orleans – a move which would eventually return the NBA to that city
since the [Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz") moved to [Salt Lake
City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City "Salt Lake City") in 1979. Before the Hornets were
eliminated from the playoffs, the NBA approved the move. As part of a deal,
the NBA promised that Charlotte would get a new team, which took the court two
years later as the [Charlotte
Bobcats](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets#2004.E2.80.932014:_Charlotte_Bobcats_era
"Charlotte Hornets").

In a 2008 interview with the _[Charlotte Observer](/wiki/Charlotte_Observer
"Charlotte Observer")_ , Shinn, who has not returned to Charlotte since the
Hornets moved, admitted that the "bad judgment I made in my life" played a
role in the Hornets' departure. He also said that if he had it to do all over
again, he would not have withdrawn from the public after the sexual assault
trial. Shinn emphasized how he was making amends by committing to New Orleans
saying, "I've made enough mistakes in my life. I'm not going to make one here.
This city needs us here. We're going to make this (New Orleans) thing
work."[12]

### 2002–2005: Early years in New
Orleans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 2002–2005: Early years in New Orleans")]

The Hornets opened [their inaugural
season](/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_New_Orleans_Hornets_season "2002–03 New Orleans
Hornets season") in New Orleans on October 30, 2002, against New Orleans'
original NBA franchise, the now-[Utah Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz"). In
the first regular season NBA game played in New Orleans in over 17 years,[13]
the Hornets defeated the Jazz 100–75, and posthumously retired #7 of ["Pistol"
Pete Maravich](/wiki/Pete_Maravich "Pete Maravich") during halftime. The
Hornets finished the season with a 47–35 record but were defeated by the
[Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers") in the
first round of the [playoffs](/wiki/2003_NBA_Playoffs "2003 NBA Playoffs").
Following the season, the team unexpectedly fired head coach [Paul
Silas](/wiki/Paul_Silas "Paul Silas") and replaced him with Alan Bristow. The
Hornets began the [2003–04 season](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_NBA_season "2003–04
NBA season") strong with a 17–7 start but sputtered at the end and finished
41–41. They lost to the [Miami Heat](/wiki/Miami_Heat "Miami Heat") in the
first round of the [2004 playoffs](/wiki/2004_NBA_Playoffs "2004 NBA
Playoffs"). After the season, Floyd was fired and the team hired [Byron
Scott](/wiki/Byron_Scott_\(basketball\) "Byron Scott \(basketball\)") as its
new head coach.

During the first two seasons in New Orleans the Hornets competed in the NBA's
[Eastern Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference
\(NBA\)"). The [2004–05 season](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_NBA_season "2004–05 NBA
season") saw the team moved to the [Western
Conference](/wiki/Western_Conference_\(NBA\) "Western Conference \(NBA\)")'s
[Southwest Division](/wiki/Southwest_Division_\(NBA\) "Southwest Division
\(NBA\)"). In a season marred by injury to the team's three all-stars, the
team finished the year with a franchise-worst record of 18–64.

### 2005–2011: Chris Paul
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: 2005–2011: Chris Paul era")]

In the [subsequent draft](/wiki/2005_NBA_draft "2005 NBA draft"), the Hornets
used their first round pick to select [point guard](/wiki/Point_guard "Point
guard") [Chris Paul](/wiki/Chris_Paul "Chris Paul") out of [Wake Forest
University](/wiki/Wake_Forest_University "Wake Forest University").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chris_Paul.jpg/180px-
Chris_Paul.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chris_Paul.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chris_Paul.jpg "Enlarge")

[Chris Paul](/wiki/Chris_Paul "Chris Paul"), selected by the Hornets as the
4th pick of the [2005 NBA draft](/wiki/2005_NBA_draft "2005 NBA draft")

Because of the catastrophic devastation brought by [Hurricane
Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina") upon the communities of
southeastern [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), the Hornets franchise
[temporarily
relocated](/wiki/Effect_of_Hurricane_Katrina_on_the_New_Orleans_Hornets
"Effect of Hurricane Katrina on the New Orleans Hornets") its base of
operations to [Oklahoma City, Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma_City "Oklahoma City"),
in 2005–06 and 2006–07, posting records of 38–44 and 39–43 respectively.[14]
During this time, the franchise was known as the **New Orleans/Oklahoma City
Hornets**. In these two seasons, most home games were played at the [Ford
Center](/wiki/Chesapeake_Energy_Arena "Chesapeake Energy Arena") in Oklahoma
City, while a few remained at New Orleans Arena. One year after the Hornets
moved back to New Orleans permanently, the [Seattle
SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics")
[relocated](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics_relocation_to_Oklahoma_City "Seattle
SuperSonics relocation to Oklahoma City") to Oklahoma City and became the
[Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder").

The Hornets franchise returned to New Orleans full-time for the 2007–08
season, with all 41 home games in the New Orleans Arena. The 2008 [NBA All-
Star Game](/wiki/NBA_All-Star_Game "NBA All-Star Game") and its accompanying
festivities were awarded to New Orleans and a serious marketing campaign was
commenced in February 2007. Healthier than previous seasons, the Hornets raced
to a 29–12 record at the halfway mark, completing the regular season with a
record of 56–26, making the season their most successful ever. The Hornets
also won their first-ever division title, winning the [Southwest
Division](/wiki/Southwest_Division_\(NBA\) "Southwest Division \(NBA\)").
Having clinched the 2nd overall seed for the Western Conference in the [2008
playoffs](/wiki/2008_NBA_Playoffs "2008 NBA Playoffs"), the Hornets beat the
[Dallas Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") in the first
round but eventually lost to the defending-champion [San Antonio
Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs") in seven games in the
conference semifinals.

In August 2008 the Hornets unveiled a modified logo and new uniforms with the
colors of Creole blue, purple, and [Mardi Gras](/wiki/Mardi_Gras "Mardi Gras")
gold. Pinstripes were also added to the uniforms. The Hornets also introduced
a new gold alternate uniform in 2010 which was used mostly in games played on
Saturday at home and on the road. The Hornets finished the [2008–09
season](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_NBA_season "2008–09 NBA season") with a 49–33
record. Paired up with the [Denver Nuggets](/wiki/Denver_Nuggets "Denver
Nuggets") in the first round of the [2009 NBA
Playoffs](/wiki/2009_NBA_Playoffs "2009 NBA Playoffs"), the Hornets were
eliminated in five games. The Hornets started the [2009–10
season](/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_NBA_season "2009–10 NBA season") in a
disappointing fashion, and head coach [Byron
Scott](/wiki/Byron_Scott_\(basketball\) "Byron Scott \(basketball\)") was
fired after a 3–6 start to the season. General manager [Jeff
Bower](/wiki/Jeff_Bower_\(basketball\) "Jeff Bower \(basketball\)") took over
the head coaching duties for the remainder of the season. The Hornets finished
the season with a 37–45 record, finishing last in the Southwest division they
had won only two seasons before. Jeff Bower later resigned as head coach, and
[Monty Williams](/wiki/Monty_Williams "Monty Williams") was brought in as new
head coach. The team finished the [2010–11
season](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_NBA_season "2010–11 NBA season") with a 46–36
record and qualified for the [2011 NBA Playoffs](/wiki/2011_NBA_Playoffs "2011
NBA Playoffs"), where they lost to the Lakers 4–2.

In December 2010 the NBA purchased the Hornets from [George
Shinn](/wiki/George_Shinn "George Shinn") for an estimated $300
million.[15][16]

### 2011–2013: CP3's departure; beginning the Anthony Davis
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 2011–2013: CP3's departure; beginning the Anthony Davis era")]

Before the 2011–12 NBA season, the Hornets were considering trade offers for
Chris Paul. Paul eventually requested a trade to the [New York
Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks"). The Hornets looked at many
teams, including the [Boston Celtics](/wiki/Boston_Celtics "Boston Celtics")
and the [Golden State Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State
Warriors") as trade partners, but Paul had made it clear he wanted to be
traded to New York or Los Angeles. A three-team trade involving the [Los
Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") and the
[Houston Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets") was agreed upon,
but commissioner [David Stern](/wiki/David_Stern "David Stern") vetoed the
trade.[17] On December 14, 2011, the Hornets agreed to a deal with the [Los
Angeles Clippers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Clippers "Los Angeles Clippers") that
would send Paul to L.A. in exchange for [Eric Gordon](/wiki/Eric_Gordon "Eric
Gordon"), [Chris Kaman](/wiki/Chris_Kaman "Chris Kaman"), [Al-Farouq
Aminu](/wiki/Al-Farouq_Aminu "Al-Farouq Aminu"), and a first-round draft pick
acquired by the Clippers from a trade with the [Minnesota
Timberwolves](/wiki/Minnesota_Timberwolves "Minnesota Timberwolves") in 2004.

At the end of the 66-game lockout-shortened [2011–12 NBA
season](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_NBA_season "2011–12 NBA season"), the Hornets
had the worst record in the West, 21–45.

On April 13, 2012, it was announced that [Tom Benson](/wiki/Tom_Benson "Tom
Benson"), owner of the [New Orleans Saints](/wiki/New_Orleans_Saints "New
Orleans Saints"), had purchased the franchise from the NBA for $338
million.[18][19] In addition, Benson announced that he would change the team
name to something that would better suit the region, fueling rumors that the
Hornets name could one day return to Charlotte, where the
[Bobcats](/wiki/Charlotte_Bobcats "Charlotte Bobcats") play.[20][21] In June
2012, Benson appointed two senior Saints executives to supervise the Hornets
as well: Saints general manager [Mickey Loomis](/wiki/Mickey_Loomis "Mickey
Loomis") became head of basketball operations, overseeing general manager
[Dell Demps](/wiki/Dell_Demps "Dell Demps"), and Saints business operations
head Dennis Lauscha took on the same role with the Hornets.[22]

The Hornets traded [Emeka Okafor](/wiki/Emeka_Okafor "Emeka Okafor") and
[Trevor Ariza](/wiki/Trevor_Ariza "Trevor Ariza") to the Wizards for [Rashard
Lewis](/wiki/Rashard_Lewis "Rashard Lewis"), whom they bought out, and a draft
pick.

On May 30, 2012, the Hornets were awarded the first overall pick in the [2012
NBA draft](/wiki/2012_NBA_draft "2012 NBA draft") and subsequently drafted
[Anthony Davis](/wiki/Anthony_Davis_\(basketball\) "Anthony Davis
\(basketball\)"). They also drafted [Austin Rivers](/wiki/Austin_Rivers
"Austin Rivers") with the 10th pick (acquired from the Clippers as part of the
Chris Paul trade).

On July 11, 2012, [Ryan
Anderson](/wiki/Ryan_Anderson_\(basketball,_born_1988\) "Ryan Anderson
\(basketball, born 1988\)"), 2012's Most Improved Player and three-point field
goals leader, was acquired in a sign-and-trade by the New Orleans Hornets,
with the [Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic"), for [Gustavo
Ayón](/wiki/Gustavo_Ay%C3%B3n "Gustavo Ayón").

### 2013–present: The Pelicans take
flight[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: 2013–present: The Pelicans take flight")]

New owner Tom Benson had indicated early in his ownership that he wished to
change the team's name to something more local, even preferring that the [Utah
Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz") – founded in [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans") in 1974 and played there until 1979,
give up the "**Jazz** " name. But the Jazz indicated they had no interest in
returning the name due to over 30 years of history associated with it. Benson
had also heavily favored the names "Brass" and "Krewe".

However, on December 4, 2012, it was reported that the Hornets would change
their name to the New Orleans Pelicans beginning with the 2013–14 season.[23]
The team name is inspired by Louisiana's state bird, the [brown
pelican](/wiki/Brown_pelican "Brown pelican").[24]

The name "Pelicans" previously had been used by a [minor-league baseball
team](/wiki/New_Orleans_Pelicans_\(baseball\) "New Orleans Pelicans
\(baseball\)") that played in New Orleans from 1901 to 1957.[25] The Hornets
organization officially confirmed the name change in a press conference held
on January 24, 2013, where officials unveiled the team's new logos and navy
blue–gold–red color scheme.[7][26] On April 18, 2013, after the end of the
team's 2012–13 season, the team's name was officially changed to the
Pelicans.[27]

Following the New Orleans franchise's 2013 disestablishment of the "Hornets"
name, on May 21, 2013, [Charlotte Bobcats](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets "Charlotte
Hornets") owner [Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan")
officially announced the organization had submitted an application to change
the name of his franchise to the Charlotte Hornets for the 2014–15
[NBA](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball Association")
season pending a majority vote for approval by the NBA Board of Governors at a
meeting in [Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas"), on July 18, 2013.[28]
Then-NBA Deputy Commissioner and COO [Adam Silver](/wiki/Adam_Silver "Adam
Silver") had previously pointed out the fact that the league owns the rights
to the name Hornets and that could speed up the process.[29] The NBA
unanimously approved the name change starting with 2014–15.[30]

On June 27, 2013, during the [2013 NBA draft](/wiki/2013_NBA_draft "2013 NBA
draft"), the Pelicans selected Nerlens Noel 6th overall, and traded him along
with a 2014 protected first-round pick for [All-Star](/wiki/NBA_All-Star_Game
"NBA All-Star Game") point guard [Jrue Holiday](/wiki/Jrue_Holiday "Jrue
Holiday") of the [Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia
76ers") and the 42nd pick, [Pierre Jackson](/wiki/Pierre_Jackson "Pierre
Jackson").[31] At a May 20, 2014 press conference announcing the [Charlotte
Bobcats](/wiki/Charlotte_Bobcats "Charlotte Bobcats")' official team name
change to Hornets, it was also announced that the Pelicans agreed to transfer
the records and statistics of the original Hornets (1988–2002) to the current
Charlotte franchise, thus unifying all of Charlotte's NBA basketball history
under one franchise; the team records and statistics since the 2002 move to
New Orleans would be retained by the Pelicans, retroactively turning the
Pelicans into a 2002 [expansion team](/wiki/Expansion_team "Expansion
team").[1]

To restate and clarify a confusing series of events: after the 2002 season,
the original Hornets moved to New Orleans. In 2004, Charlotte was granted a
new franchise, the Bobcats. After the 2013–14 season, the Bobcats changed
their name to the Hornets and reclaimed the history and records of the
1988–2002 Hornets. As a result, the Hornets are now reckoned as having
suspended operations from 2002 to 2004, while the Pelicans are now reckoned as
having joined the league in 2002.

#### 2015: Return to the
playoffs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 2015: Return to the playoffs")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Alvin_Gentry_in_2015.jpg/170px-
Alvin_Gentry_in_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alvin_Gentry_in_2015.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Alvin_Gentry_in_2015.jpg "Enlarge")

Alvin Gentry is the New Orleans Pelicans current head coach.

For the first time under the name Pelicans, the team qualified for the
[playoffs](/wiki/2015_NBA_Playoffs "2015 NBA Playoffs") with a 45–37 record as
the number 8 seed in the Western Conference. They owned the tie-breaker over
the [Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Oklahoma_City_Thunder_season
"2014–15 Oklahoma City Thunder season") by winning the regular season head-to-
head series 3–1, and they faced the [Golden State
Warriors](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Golden_State_Warriors_season "2014–15 Golden
State Warriors season") in the first round; the Warriors swept the Pelicans in
four games. After the season, the Pelicans fired coach [Monty
Williams](/wiki/Monty_Williams "Monty Williams") despite qualifying for the
playoffs.

On May 31, 2015, the Pelicans hired [Alvin Gentry](/wiki/Alvin_Gentry "Alvin
Gentry") as the franchise's 6th head coach.[32]

#### 2017–present: Davis and Cousins
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 2017–present: Davis and Cousins era")]

On February 20, 2017, Pelicans acquired [DeMarcus
Cousins](/wiki/DeMarcus_Cousins "DeMarcus Cousins") in a trade with the
[Sacramento Kings](/wiki/Sacramento_Kings "Sacramento Kings") when they traded
[Buddy Hield](/wiki/Buddy_Hield "Buddy Hield"), [Tyreke
Evans](/wiki/Tyreke_Evans "Tyreke Evans"), [Langston
Galloway](/wiki/Langston_Galloway "Langston Galloway"), a 2017 1st round pick,
and a 2017 2nd round pick in exchange for Cousins and [Omri
Casspi](/wiki/Omri_Casspi "Omri Casspi").

## Logos and
uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Logos and uniforms")]

The New Orleans Hornets were sold to Tom Benson on April 13, 2012.[18] After
purchasing the team, Benson indicated that he wanted to change the club's
nickname to something more regionally appropriate. On December 14, 2012, it
was reported that the Hornets would change their nickname to the New Orleans
Pelicans.[23] On January 24, 2013, the team held a press conference, where it
unveiled its new nickname, logos and colors. The name Pelicans is a reference
to the [brown pelican](/wiki/Brown_pelican "Brown pelican"), the state bird of
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana").[7][24] The team said in a press
release that its colors would be navy, gold and red; each color is represented
in the city [flag of New Orleans](/wiki/Flag_of_New_Orleans "Flag of New
Orleans").[26] The team formally adopted its new brand identity at the end of
the [2012–13 NBA season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NBA_season "2012–13 NBA
season").[27]

On August 1, 2013, the Pelicans released their new uniforms. The 'New Orleans'
wordmark logo across the front of the jerseys is inspired by [French
Quarter](/wiki/French_Quarter "French Quarter") street signs; the Pelicans are
one of three NBA teams to wear the city name across the front of both home and
road jerseys. The partial logo is featured on the sides of the shorts, and the
"Bird-de-Lis" logo (a combination mark of the pelican, [fleur-de-
lis](/wiki/Fleur-de-lis "Fleur-de-lis") and crescent basketball shape) is
featured on the back neck.[33][34][35][36] NBA teams were not allowed to have
alternate uniforms during their first season of operation.

On September 23, 2014, the Pelicans unveiled a red alternate uniform for the
2014–15 season that would be worn four times in the year.[37] Prior to the red
alternate uniform unveiling, the NBA announced that its league logo would be
moved to the back neck of game jerseys for all 30 clubs; as a result, the NBA
league logo replaced the "Bird-de-Lis" logo on the back neck.[38][39]

On September 17, 2015, the Pelicans unveiled a new alternate uniform,
introduced as part of the NBA's "Pride" uniforms for the [2015–16
season](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_NBA_season "2015–16 NBA season"). The short-
sleeved uniforms feature [Mardi Gras](/wiki/New_Orleans_Mardi_Gras "New
Orleans Mardi Gras")' signature colors – purple, green and gold. The tops are
purple with green accents on the sleeves and sport
'[NOLA](/wiki/Nola_\(disambiguation\)#Places "Nola \(disambiguation\)")' (a
local acronym for New Orleans, Louisiana) across the chest in the Pelicans’
signature font in gold letters trimmed in green. The Pelicans 'NO' logo is
featured at the bottom of the v-neck and the Crescent City basketball logo is
on the left sleeve in Mardi Gras colors. Additionally, the trim around the
neckline is purple, green and gold-striped. Additionally, on the back of the
jersey, the players’ numbers will be gold with green trim, last name in white
traditional lettering and the NBA logo will be featured at the base of the
neck. The purple shorts will have green and gold stripes down the side with a
small secondary logo – the "Bird-de-Lis" in gold centered on the waistband.
The Pelicans’ partial logo is on both sides of the shorts in Mardi Gras
colors.[40]

##
Mascot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Orleans_Pelicans&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Mascot")]

**Pierre the Pelican** is the official mascot for the Pelicans. He was
introduced on October 30, 2013, the opening night of regular season for the
team at home against the [Indiana Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana
Pacers").[44][45] The name for the mascot was selected by the fans through an
online poll on the team's website. However, Pierre's unconventional design
frightened some fans. The mascot's redesigned head was released on February
11.[46] The Pelicans' prior mascot was [Hugo the Hornet](/wiki/Hugo_\(mascot\)
"Hugo \(mascot\)"), who was part of the organization from 2002–13. Hugo
returned as the mascot for the [Charlotte Hornets](/wiki/Charlotte_Hornets
"Charlotte Hornets") starting with the 2014–15 season.[47]
